name: (2S,5s)-2,5-hexanediol
Reason: The compound (2S,5S)-2,5-hexanediol has two hydroxyl (OH) groups and a chiral carbon arrangement. Starting with the basic unit, hexane (a 6-carbon chain alkane), which has a melting point of approximately -95°C, each hydroxyl group would typically increase the melting point due to the ability to form hydrogen bonds. The hydroxyl group might raise the melting point approximately +100°C on introducing hydrogen bonding capability. The two hydroxyl groups together therefore contribute about +200°C. Chirality does not significantly affect the melting point unless it leads to crystal formation which can be the case in pure enantiomer forms and can add some degree of increased melting point, but for general prediction this effect will not be quantified due to its variability. The presence of two methyl (CH3) branches slightly increases the melting point compared to a straight chain due to increased molecular weight and a slight increase in van der Waals forces; this might contribute around +5°C for each methyl group. Consequently, the overall predicted melting point is adjusted from hexane by accounting for the impact of the functional groups present.
